author: xythobuz

description.text:
For the back of a kitchen or other drawer. This is the bracket that holds the back of the drawer up by grabbing onto a bar mounted in the ceiling of the space where the drawer slides back into the cabinet. It's customizable, so you can re-size it to fit the size of the bar. Note: They often make the narrow part of the bar slightly thicker in the center of the bar to keep the drawer from slamming. Make the space between the fingers, the "guideMount" variable a bit larger than you think it needs to be. The story of how this came to be:
So it finally happened: I got a 3D printer, and something broke that I could print a replacement for: A drawer guide bracket. It only took about 100 lines of code in OpenSCAD, a bit under 3 hours of printing (which I had to keep an eye on) and then once I had it installed and working (me being all proud at that point) my loving wife told me "You do know that those are about a dollar at the hardware store right?" I'm considering divorce. ,o)

Take the measurements from the drawer guide rail and fill out in Customizer. Save and print. Mount, slide, in bask in the glory of having spent 3 hours printing a part that you can buy at the hardware store for $2.

comments.text: And it failed yesterday. So expect it to last about 6 months if you print it from PLA. Let me know if anyone prints one in ABS. And now off to the hardware store for a real one...

print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine in white PLA which works great with Cyanoacrylate glue and matches my white shutters.

description.text:
My house has some of the old style narrow wooden shutters. The wooden pin which the shutter slats pivot on can easily break leaving the shutter slats laying crooked. This design creates a replacement pin with a flat piece of plastic to glue the replacement pin to the shutter slat.

To use this part first make sure the hole in the frame is clear and is about 1/4" in diameter. Make sure that the end of the shutter slat is smooth and no remains of the pin are present. a utility knife or file can be used to clean up the end. Next place the replacement pin in the matching hole on the frame and put a small amount of gel type Cyanoacrylate glue on the flat plastic wing. Do not glue the pin onto the slat because you won't be able to put it into the shutter frame. I know I show a photo of a pin glued to the end. I had one slat with both ends broken off so I could glue one pin directly to the slat. Make sure not to get any glue on the pin or between the frame and the wing. Move the shutter slat into place and hold for 60 seconds. You can also use masking tape to hold it in place while the glue dries.

The photos show an earlier design without tapered wings. The latest design has tapered wings and a round central portion. I've also included the simpler rectangular wing style which is shown in the photos.

title: amoeba striker hop arm (semi finale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
SEE LINK BELOW FOR NEW VERSION FOR HEAVIER BBS AND BETTER CONSISTENCY

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2789790

this is a working semi final version of my amoeba striker hop up arm for the stock hop chamber. the idea behind this it to allow some up and down "play" in the hop arm to allow the bb to pass the hop with maximum contact and minimum resistance.

this is not a standalone part and requires something compressible and elastic to go between the hop screw and the hop arm. There is about 2mm of extra space for this and i have used half a 4mm air hose placed along (not across) the arm to great effect.

it does require some sanding (took me less than 30 seconds) to get it to fit as i tried and tried to get it the right length to fit in the chamber but in the end i decided it was simpler and more precise to just sand with a high grit sand paper.

i would say i maybe got a very slight range increase over the concave hop arm on Thingiverse but consistency is through the roof.

Disclaimer: designed around a maple leaf barrel and hop rubber. I have only had .28g bbs to test so far but it will hop them to almost verticle so there should be no issues with more heavy bbs.

author: MrSlayton

description.text:
Why I did the thing

I have a dual-boot tablet that has all the ports aligned on one side, and it seemed perfect for a docking station. Rather than simply designing a one-off specific to an odd tablet, I tried to create a flexible design that could be used for other tablets or phones as well.

How I did the thing

I liked telepath's Elliptic tablet stand so I used that as the starting point, but modified the code to make it Customizer-friendly. (You can also download the scad if you prefer)

When it came to the shelf design it took a lot of patience to get just right. There's a lot of test code commented in the scad file that you may find helpful. Some suggestions:

  • Make your measurements with the cables plugged in.
  • Look for nice, plain, square or perfectly evenly round cables
  • Print out some shelves with a very low thickness to make sure everything's lined up just right.
  • If you set the diameter (or the width or height) to zero, you can have fewer ports.

Now you build a thing :)

If you happen to have a Teclast T16 Power, then the defaults will work nicely for you. Otherwise, you should be able to use Customizer to do what you'd like! You can add up to three circular ports and 3 rectangular ports, then generate both the stand and the shelf. I recommend setting the shelf thickness to a very, very low value for a few test prints while you get the alignment and sizing just right.

I can't wait to see what designs derive from this!

81 x 49 x 18mm

35min print

title: Tecsun/Grundig/Kaito AN-200 Loop Antenna Radio holder

description.text:
So you want better reception on your medium wave radio. A good alternative is a cheap tunable Loop Antenna, like the Tecsun/Grundig/Kaito AN-200. Finally you can listen to propaganda from Cuba, or maybe some obscure Russian station! Bliss!

Optimal placement of the radio vs. the antenna is important. I got fed up off having to constantly orient the radio to get the most out of the antenna. So here is a holder to keep the radio at an optimum position and stay there. I'm using it with my Tecsun PL-880, but should work with any portable MW radio. The holder is exact enough to just snap on to the loop antenna. Strong enough to hold a portable radio.

Why listen to AM radio? If you have to ask, you're a whippersnapper and are up way beyond your bed time.

Ok, I admit it, I'm an old fart interested in ancient technology...

description.text:
Decided to build a LED swing arm work flood lamp and needed some knobs that I could loosen and adjust the light to another position with out the use of a wrench. The normal round knobs just didn't feel right plus I wanted something with a little more torque to really hold the flood light steady, so I designed this. The hardware I used was 5/16" so I designed it to use a 5/16" nut. Printed it inverted so the only supports needed were the inside area where the nuts goes, I also printed this with 100% infill to make it strong (I print only in ABS so it's really strong anyways). The nut simply drops into the hex hole and is held in place by the bolt so I didn't glue it into the handle, if this is something you going to unscrew completely then you may consider a dab or two of epoxy to hold it in place. Right now this is only for a 5/16" nut to go into so you can re-scale it to fit any size you need, I many upload a 1/4", and 3/8" size at another time.

UPDATE: I just added a 1/4" version

FlashForge

Printer:

Notes:

Raft or no raft? Up to you! I like rafts because even it the print bed is a little unlevel the raft will make up for it, and with this having the internal supports for the nut area it allows better adhesion for them.

Clear out supports. if the nut is really tight going into the hole you can always use a bolt to pull it into the bottom of it. I left a little wiggle room in the design due to printing in ABS and allowing shrinkage.

title: Tronxy MGN12 2020 Carriage for E3d V6

description.text:
This is a work in progress. This has not been tested.

I was inspired to do this based on rothnic's non-linear rail project. here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2780420

I embarked down the road of linear rails for the y-carriage. The x carriage though, was bothering me. Only one side of support, no built-in belt alignment, limited hotend compatibility, and I would need to stack lots of parts to get it all to go together.

So I designed this. Did it in a couple hours but the spacing is about right for 12mm pulleys.

-28mm belt spacing
-Same width as stock plate
-Weight savings over stacked 3d printed parts with hardware
-Maintains stock x-stop.
-Compatible with front fan mounts for the CR-10 modular e3dv6 mount.
-Plan to add compatibility for side mounts
-Designed for MGN 12H carriage
-Keeps the hot end closer to the carriage compared to stock with printed parts. 1-2mm savings
-Uses common M3 hardware
-M3 nut recesses are designed to be tight so you are not pushing your nuts out.
-Low tolerance, only a couple tenths of a mil for slop so be sure to print slowly.

I plan to create y-carriages, corner mounts, and maybe motor towers to go with this. If you test it, please let me know the results!

Corner Bracket: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2788759

My parts are stuck in limbo so my printer is offline for the time being.

UPDATE: 2-9-18
Modified for MGN12H rails... which are actually what I ordered. Removed 4mm of extrusion on the mount after more carefully examining the E3d drawings. Yay! More clearance!

EDIT: 2-10-18. Tried to credit someone for design idea by posting a remix. Did not go well. I have removed my Y-brackets. Those will be a private project people can request from me directly as they need.

title: Cobra HISS Arctic (GI Joe)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I saw a picture for a winter version of the HISS so I made it. The treads have more detail and assembly is a little easier than the standard version I posted in 2015. I used an old toy and a pair of 6 inch calipers to create this 3D file, though I estimated the missiles, blanket, and side rack. As usual, the file is modeled at the size of the actual toy but is intended to be printed at 25%. If you print this larger or smaller it may have too much or too little detail.

I've printed these files but have not painted them yet. I'll post pics after I've painted a few of them.

Print the chassis in 'right-side up' orientation with supports.
Treads are printed with the "hubcaps" pointed up.
I had better luck printing the missiles horizontal and than cleaning off supports - though this part was designed to be printed pointed up so that might work better for you.

Much respect and gratitude to past and present members of our Armed Forces, you are the “Real American Heroes”. Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these.

This file is free to download. Please note that it is listed as “non-commercial”. Neither you nor I are allowed to buy or sell physical copies of this 3D model. You are allowed (and encouraged) to print copies for your own personal use. If you have downloaded this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission. Thank you for respecting the rights of the original copyright holder.

description.text: Designed to hang a set of wooden kitchen utensils.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Sill in progress:

So one day I was building a truckputer because I was severely disappointed with Panafonic chinesium poor quality receivers. So I bought a 7" 800*480 LCD and driver board from ol' ebay and then played with it. Long story short (too late???) I never finished that project. Now I had an LCD and driver. Cool, I'll do another Pi project! Wait, what, there's an official LCD???? Now I have a spare LCD and driver board.

I've always wanted a second monitor for my laptop. Why? Bug off, because I said so! Oh, wait, fair question. Sometimes I'll be coding in Arduino or OpenSCAD where I can benefit from a full screen for the app but I also want a document opened or a video playing to adorn my monotony. Now I have one.

I'm using HDMI as my laptop has HDMI out but I also have VGA and composite video in as options.

As it sits, my design is functional. My next steps are to integrate the laptop mount in to the design, make the case tool-less, and add the button panel (which isn't NECESSARY but might as well)

Ask away if you have questions. A link to a nearly identical product is listed below. This was made in Tinkercad and I'd gladly share the original project for anyone that wants to change it.

The clips that hold the second screen to the laptop are basic and will be turned in to their own thing so they can be customized.

Product link: https://www.amazon.com/SainSmart-Display-AT070TN90-Controller-Raspberry/dp/B00GZCHHIU

Please note that the driver board and LCD I bought had a longer cable for the LCD so I'm not 100% sure if the LCD and board in that link would align properly in this case.

Here's my Tinkercad design: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cJiti7FLNAE-lcd-case/
There's lots of spare parts there so don't freak out, print what you need. It's still in progress. Next iteration will have the button board incorporated (I didn't think I'd ever switch settings. WRONG!!!).

title: MyRCCar Suspension System for various CVDs including C-Hubs, 6 types of Steering Blocks and 2 different lower arms

description.text:
So this is the end of this saga to build your own rc car, the #5th chapter!!! The suspension. In spanish we say "suspense" and that's why i let it for the end...

But also because is now when more decisive your selection is. You have to select the right CVD to acomplish the kind of car you want. Shorter ones will be needed to build On road cars or scale cars, and bigger ones to build a buggy, truggy or short course car.

I have seen unbelieveable prices for HSP CVDs coming from china but also i think they are some of the most extended and the references are clear.

I have spent some time researching about CVDs and i have seen there are at least 3 types. The first type are the ones i got from the Vandal or the ones i bought for about 60€ for the OpenRC Truggy, same price than whole vandal kit.

TYPEA Steering Blocks are designed for this kind of CVDs. They use two 5x10x4 bearings each.

TYPEB Steering Blocks are for HSP 122015 and HSP 166015. They use one 5x10x4 bearing and other 10x15x4 bearing each

TYPEC Steering Blocks are like B but the bearings have a little different possition. They would be HSP 102015 and HSP 106015

As you can see in the drawings, i have made the arms for at least 2 kind of CVD length. You can use the short one, MRCC_SUS_LA475 to build an onroad or scale car and MRCC_SUS_LA715 to build an off-road car.

So that's it! Print your 4 lower arms and C-hubs, then print two front and two rear steering blocks of the correct type for your CVDs.

I'll post the rest of the info to build a whole car in the related MyRCCar Group. Please join us or make your questions there if they are not directly related to this thing

title: Screwdriver Racks with French Cleat hangers

description.text:
This thing is a set of caddies for my Wiha SoftFinish 20 piece screwdriver set. I grouped the screwdrivers by type and designed a caddy for each group -- Phillips/Pozidriv, Robertson, Slotted, and Torx. Each caddy has a corresponding French cleat attachment that can slide on the back with French dovetails.

Note: the versions I've uploaded here are tweaked and updated from the versions I printed myself -- the two-level design is new, I fine-tuned the dovetail slides, made them all a uniform depth, and I removed a side-attachment feature that didn't really work out. I haven't printed the new versions, since the originals work well enough for me, but if anyone has trouble with printing, or notices a problem with spacing please let me know and I'll make adjustments.

Printer:

Creality Ender-2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print the cleats upside-down so that the main body doesn't need any support material. Printed that way you'll need supports for the dovetails on the cleat pieces, but that should be it -- I use slic3r and as far as I know supports are automatically generated and they're all-or-nothing, so I tend to get supports inside the dovetails on the caddie pieces as well. This support can be a pain in the butt to remove cleanly, so it may be worth printing the pieces on two plates.

These models are sized to be printed in PETG, not PLA. As I understand it PLA shrinks more than PETG, so you may find you need to scale the model up by 1 or 2 percent to get it to fit right.

Chances are you'll need to file or sand down the dovetails to get the fit right. On the ones I printed they fit, but they're a tight enough fit that it's pretty much permanent. I had intended for these to be able to be removed and potentially swapped out with pieces to make a free standing rack for them, but haven't done the design or tuning for them yet.

This is remix of Y-visor for VertexEvo printer.

After adding print-bed side support and extending print area along Y-axis I discovered that the original visor hits the top piece of right support before print-head reaches new Y=0 position. So I completely redesigned the visor and publishing it here.

You will need three M3 self-locking nuts, one M3x25mm and one M3x16mm screws. Optionally, to add slightly more weight to the front side of the visor, you can use one more M3x16mm screw and M3 nut.

The images show how to put things together. Make sure that Y-visor_part3 moves freely and closes Y-stop sensor only when pushed towards the back of the printer by XY_clamp.

Fan duct is pictured mounted to my Auto Levelling Carriage but will work with the standard E3Dv6 carriage that i have designed also, no mods are needed to the existing carriage if you already have it fitted, just print this duct and bolt it on!

remixed_from.title: Extruder upgrade flexible filament for Creality CR-7 CR-10 Afinibot A5 - A31

description.text:
This is a new extruder body based on the one by danid87 - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2604173 - with an integrated filament sensor housing. It's made specifically for relocated extruders, it will not fit in the stock location. Should work fine for top mounting the extruder or moving it to the end of the X axis arm as I've done.

What I've done is print out the extruder relocator bracket from PENBERIC - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2672088 - but I'm turning my extruder 90* so that the Bowden tube exits upwards and arcs over to the hot end. I'll be pulling filament up through a hole next to the printer from my drybox once I get my cabinet built. This should work fine and be lower drag than turning the filament vertical and then back horizontal with pulleys or something.

Of course it will need plenty of supports, print as oriented in the attached screenshot. I find with Cura that a 10% support density with dense support interfaces turned on leaves a nice enough surface and fairly easy to remove with a .4mm air gap.

Update: V3 is the final revision. Printed one out and the problems from before have been fixed. Noticed in the slicer that V2 somehow ended up with a tiny space between the switch box and the extruder plate, it would have made it weak. Updated and printed out V3 and it's fine. I'm calling it ready to go.

comments.text: I'm modifying this further, combining the mounting plate and the extruder into one piece and making the plate thicker. Also planning to add a mount for Stevenfayer's Z axis drag chain. Should be finished and have it uploaded in a day or two.

description.text:

How you can check:

  • outer gimbal diameter (top circle): 48mm

This thing is part of an instructable on how to recycle spent desiccant dehumidifiers. (the kind with the hygroscopic calcium chloride salt inside)
They are frequently used around the tropics to keep moist out of cupboards and storage rooms, but quite a few makers use dehumidifiers as well to dry out filament before printing. If you are interested in recycling your spend calcium chloride desiccant dehumidifiers, check out the instructable too:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Recycle-desiccant-dehumidifiers-Thirsty-hippos/ This dehumidifier is constructed out of breakfast oats containers with some printed parts. It's meant to be hung by the handle in a cupboard, to prevent it from ever topping over.

Find one of these containers, or similar. reservoir.scad relies on meshscreen.scad to generate its mesh bottom.
The scad files are fully parametrized and can be tailored to fit a different size containers. Tweak the setting of the mesh screen to fit your printer settings. It is a good idea to set the with of the mesh threads to a multiple of the width of your extruded filament.
Idem ditto for the mesh height: set it to a multiple of your printers layer height for best results. I print with a layer height of 0.3 and a width of 0.45. My mesh is set to be 1.2 mm high, the threads are 0.45 mm wide and spaced apart 2mm. It works really well for me that way. == Cut open the top of the container. Adjust the mesh screen to fit your container and print. Adjust the container to fit your container and print. Print the 4 legs as well. Assemble. Add calcium chloride. hang in cupboard/ put inside an airtight container together with your filament.

Scale 1:2

1 pixel in game = 2mm

I know that there are a lot of Minecraft models. But sometimes it's more fun to create it from scratch =)

title: Ball jointed cable management for Prusa MK2S/Zaribo Extruder

description.text:
This is a ball jointed cable management system for the Extruder wires on the Prusa i3 MK2s and Zaribo 3d Printers. Note that the MK2S adaptor is coming soon so this is only currently usable for the Zaribo printer. For more information on Zaribo click here - http://zaribo.org/

The same system will be coming shortly for the Z motor cables. You can find one for the heatbed here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2735303

There are 3 main elements to this system:

The Extruder Adaptor. Oh and you will need to remove the extruder heater cable connectors as they will not fit through the ball joints, they are easy to screw on/off though. Also use a tie wrap to hold the wires in place firmly.
These must be printed in the orientation of the supplied STLS, no support is needed.

Ball joints - Approximately 26 of these will be required for the Zaribo but it will depend on the length of your cables. These are printed using 'Spiralise' or 'Vase' mode without any top or bottom layers. I recommend that these be printed with PETG so they have a little flex.

The Rambo box adaptor - Zaribo - This is similar to the ball joints but is straight on one end so it can fit over the existing Rambo connection, it should be a tight-ish fit. I used some heatshrink on the cables as they enter the Rambo box to avoid any rubbing problems, however that is much less with this system and might not even be needed at all.
This adaptor must also be printed using 'Spiralise' or 'Vase' mode. I recommend that these be printed with PETG so they have a little flex.
When the ball joints are pushed together they should be quite a loose fit but not fall apart.

TIPS: When threading the wires through the ball joints, do it in segments to make it easier then just joint the segments together afterwards.

comments.text: Very Nice!    Do you think that this design will reduce cable failures?    Using the standard cable wrap, I have had a wire in my bundle get severed (mid-way in the bundle) by the continuous sawing action of the cable wrap edge.   I am wondering if your approach would be an improvement.
comments.author: DuaneIndeed

comments.text: This system shouldn't saw the cables as they don't fit around the cables as tightly. A problem I had with my MK2S was that the cables were sawn at the point they entered the Rambo box so, to fix this I put heatshrink tubing around the cables where they entered the box. I recommend doing that for this system as well because there will be some rubbing where it enters the box.
comments.author: DuaneIndeed

comments.text:
Good to hear! I found some cable advice published by the robotics industry that is relevent to 3dp.
1) Minimize/avoid tie wraps (they cut), and never over tighten.
2) Provide extra air space in the channel (your design helps with this).
3) Group like cables together, and segregate from dislike. (I suppose that cable lacing might help accomplish this).
4) Anchor at only two points, and separate anchor points from connectors.
5) The cable should follow a “neutral” (eg center) path through the channel. This means that the cable should not be too long (which forces the cable to rub against outside curved channel walls), or too short (which forces the cable to rub against inside curved channel walls).
comments.author: Jasoncanning

comments.text: There are some good tips there. What's also important is the type of cable; I replaced the heatbed cables with AWG14 which are far more flexible and robust. So far I'm pretty happy with the way these joints are working, they are by no means perfect but definitely better than the supplied cable wraps, you can also choose your colour too :)

description.text:
Looking for something cool to give to your partner this valentine? How about a pendant coded with a hidden message?

Surprise your partner with this QR code pendant/ keychain. The code says " Will you be my valentine?" upon scanning.

To print this, you have to use the pause feature on your 3D printer and you will need two filaments-prefarably white and black. I haven't tried with other colors but in theory any dark color instead of black should work too.

How to print?
Start printing with white filament and keep printing till it starts doing the embossed part. Pause the printer (I use M600 in prointerface of cura to pause) and change the filament to black and resume printing till the end.

Scan it using a QR code scanner from your smart phone and enjoy!

P.S.Only if I had someone to give this to :/

How to make a personalise QR code keychain/pendant

Step 1: Go here (https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com/) and generate a personalized QR code.

Step 2: Convert the downloaded image of QR code (Jpeg or png) to SVG format using https://convertio.co/png-svg/

Step 3: Import the SVG file into tinkercad and place it on top of a baseplate with a ring on top and group them to get the final design.

Step 4: Export as stl and print.

I wasn't really happy with the Filament spool holder of Prusa's MMU upgrade kit. Also version 2 is not really good for me. The bearing aluminium axles move sideways (the o-rings do not really help a lot) and what was not ideal was the tangling of the filament into the hotend cable mesh. So I designed something new.

Here we go:

title: 3D Printing on Fabric - Hexagon / Triangle Pattern Test

description.text:
These are some very basic geometric shapes that were made quickly in Tinkercad as a test for how you can directly print on fabric.

This is a really cool and easy project to do.

  1. Print the file
  2. Pause the printer at about the 2nd or 3rd layer
  3. Secure down some Tulle fabric http://amzn.to/2sqeroL
  4. Resume printing

If you're using simplify3d you can also insert this code into the additional terminal commands to have the printer stop at the 3rd layer, move the print head out of the way for your to secure the fabric, then allow you to resume printing

{REPLACE "\n; layer 3, Z = " "; layer 3\nG28 Y0 X0\nM300\nM25\nG92 E0\nG28 Y0 X0\n; layer 3 "}

I first saw this concept from Shorey Designs - Make sure to checkout his instagram page
https://www.instagram.com/shoreydesigns/

Here is a video of the entire process showing you how it's done
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjH5KGw3Psw&list=PL20dy8XVpbwrBz_pn7g2aQwMN3wOXomkK

Printer:

CR-10 Mini

Rafts:

Notes:

You should be able to experiment with other fabrics as well

title: Removable Drop Cup for Automatic Soap Dispenser

description.text:
The purpose of this object is to offer a clean and integrated removable cup for a cheap automatic soap dispenser.

I guess this object won't be compatible with all soap dispensers, so you should definitely check if your model is similar to the one visible on the photo. Else, you will probably have to adapt the model.

Mine is about 200ml soap dispenser, branded Thinp. The feet set in a cross disposition are quite thin.

Printer Brand:

DAGOMA

Printer:

Neva

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

17%

Notes:

I personally used rafts to prevent warping for the base.
Also, I didn't use any supports but this may be useful for the cup, depending of your printer settings. The piece is quite small, you can just make a first try without supports and add them if needed.

When we bought our automatic soap dispenser, we were quickly fed up with the soap drops that accumulated underneath. The idea was to design a nice and practical cup holder that would take care of these small drops and can be washed within a few seconds.
This current design is the second version of a first cup-holder I made.
The original one was my first design I made in DesignSpark Mechanical for 3D printing and it was not very good : I made bad and clumsy design choices, it was not really practical.
With this second iteration, I got an object that keep the dispenser centered and locked whereas the cup is designed to catch the maximum of lost soap.
Also, the railing allow to set the remoteness for a few millimeters if needed.
I don't know if this object can be useful to a lot of people but I publish it anyway.

This is a lasercut Masterspool for holding filament that you purchase without a spool.

Buying a spool with each lot of filament is wasteful and unnecessary: Richrap is championing the idea of a Masterspool - https://richrap.blogspot.de/2018/01/masterspool-proposed-standard-for-3d.html

I thought I'd do my bit and create a laser cut version for those that don't want to waste a couple hundred grams of filament on creating a spool holder.

You'll need the following:

1x Side A
1x Side B
6x Insert
3x M8x60 bolts
3x self locking nuts

The DXFs assume you're using 3.5ish mm wood.

You can buy filament without the spool here: https://www.dasfilament.de/

Update: Added some filament tie off holes to use when storing the filament

Have fun!

description.text:
About The Model

Introducing the dagger used by Ciri in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt.

A larger than expected weapon it stands at 50cm long (scaled to the game files) and the scabbard to house it is included in the files.

Support Me

Though I provide this print for free, if you'd like to shout me a coffee or support my work (Patreon's will get future files earlier than everyone else) - all of which helps me create more of these free models - you can do so on the following links:

  • Ko-fi: https://ko-fi.com/valentinecostumes
  • Patreon: https://patreon.com/valentinecostumes

Build Details

  • Space for a metal core runs through the blade and into the hilt for added strength (intended use: one 3mm x 10mm x 300mm steel rod)
  • The middle of the scabbard is intended to be covered in a 1.5mm leather outer (which will help it all stay together).

Associated Files

The heater block of 3D printers is subjected to a considerable heat loss both for exposure to air, but also for the cooling fans that inevitably also involve the nozzle.
This bi valva mold allows to create a "coat" to isolate the heater block (dimensions 16x16x12 mm) simply by screwing the mold to the thermal silicone tube and injecting into the contents.
At the bottom you can see the three pieces that make up the mold, or the two valves and the internal counter mold.
Just insert the counter mold inside the two valves by tightening them with four screws, screw the whole thing to the thermal silicone tube and squeeze it until it fills the entire mold. The drying times are shown on the type of silicone used. (G-Translate)

More Info: http://www.karnhack.com/heater-block-thermal-jacket/

description.text:
What do you do when you can't buy the Sony PSS-610 ceiling mount for your newly acquired projector? You print one!

This is a ceiling mounting bracket for the Sony VPL-AW15 and similar projectors. Print out the two brackets, use 1/4" lag bolts to secure the ceiling bracket to a ceiling joist. Purchase 1" threaded pipe from your local hardware store of the length that you want. Thread the pipe into the ceiling bracket and then thread the projector bracket onto the pipe. Use M5 screws to attach the projector to the mount. Use washers with all screws.

This part was created using Fusion360, editing McMaster-Carr files as described by Desktop Makes on YouTube on January 19th, 2018.

The ceiling bracket was printed with 60% infill from black PLA. I hung my full weight on this piece, expecting it to fail, but it did not.

We continue with the updates of the oldest OpenForge series: Dungeon Stone. Dungeon Stone finally gets the OpenLOCK treatment, with the release of Primary Walls/Primary Floors/Low Primary Walls. This set has fully adopted all the changes in OpenLOCK up to version 7.5, including for the first time OpenLOCK's new supports in the clip bay.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

You are going to first want to decide if you are going to glue pieces or not. If you don't want to glue anything, select the files named dungeon_stone_wall.inch..low.triplex.. If you want magnets, then select dungeon_stone_wall.inch..low.openforge.. It is not critical that every wall be the same.

If you are using the openforge varients, you will also need to print a base: dungeon_stone_base.inch..openlock.magnetic.

Second you will want to decide if you want sidelocking. Odds are you do. For that, select files with .side. in the name.

Finally you will want to choose if you want pegs. Pegs are used for indexing a second floor. If you never plan on building multi floor layouts, skip them. Even if you do, you may not want them on all tiles, as they can interfere with the aesthetics a little. We print them on about half of our A walls, which gives enough to index an upper layer if you want.

Starting Set

When starting out with this set, we recommend printing:

  • 20 dungeon_stone_wall.inch.A
  • 4 dungeon_stone_wall.inch.BA <- Strongly suggest you do this one in triplex even if doing magnetic for everything else
  • 8 dungeon_stone_wall.inch.G
  • 2 dungeon_stone_wall.inch.IA <- Suggest you do this one in triplex too
  • 4 dungeon_stone_floor.inch.Q
  • 4 dungeon_stone_column.inch.I.stl
  • 8 dungeon_stone_column.inch.L.stl
  • 4 dungeon_stone_column.inch.O.stl
  • 4 dungeon_stone_column.inch.X.stl
  • 4 dungeon_stone_column.inch.T.stl

If using magnets, this will require:

  • 2 * 20 = 40
  • 2 * 8 = 16
  • 4 * 4 = 16
    total: 72

If using openlock, you will want about 2 clips per tile you print, so 56.

You can use the floor tiles on their own, without walls if you like as just a way to lay out rooms. If you want walls, you can start withPrimary Walls or Low Primary Walls

You can find the rest of this set as it gets released in the OpenForge 2 Dungeon Stone Collection

Painting

This set was originally designed so I could cheaply expand on my Dwarven Forge tiles from their first Kickstarter. Because of that, the paint scheme I use is designed to make the tiles fit in with the scheme I used on that set. Dwarven Forge has a video showing how to do this paint scheme.

You are going to first want to decide if you are going to glue pieces or not. If you don't want to glue anything, select:

  • dungeon_stone_floor.inch.[letter].triplex.stl

If you want to control what kind of connectors you are using, instead select:

  • dungeon_stone_floor.inch.[letter].openforge.stl

and then select a base:

  • magnetic - has holes for captive spherical 5mm magnets along the edge, one per center of a square
  • magnetic.openlock - has holes for captive spherical 5mm magnets along the edge, one per center of a square. Also has an openlock port, one per edge between squares.
  • openlock - has an openlock port, one per edge between squares.
  • triplex - has many openlock ports, one per edge between squares and one per square.
Starting Set

When starting out with this set, we recommend printing:

  • 16 dungeon_stone_floor.inch.E
  • 8 dungeon_stone_floor.inch.F
  • 2 dungeon_stone_floor.inch.R
  • 4 dungeon_stone_floor.inch.U

If using magnets, this will require:

  • 8 * 16 = 128
  • 6 * 8 = 48
  • 2 * 8 = 16
  • 16 * 4 = 64
    total: 256

If using openlock, you will want about 2 clips per tile you print, so 54.

You can use the floor tiles on their own, without walls if you like as just a way to lay out rooms. If you want walls, you can start withPrimary Walls or Low Primary Walls

description.text:
This is a trailer in 1/87 (H0) scale for lightning of a small model scene without using external lamps. The LEDs are bright enough to provide some decent night flair.

For the lightning I used 5 Neopixel RGB LEDs and 2 red SMD LEDs (type 0603). 4 of the Neopixels are lighting the sourrounding of the trailer from the top of the mast. author: Heref

description.text: This is a wallet I designed to match my requirements. I currently use a Jimi wallet (http://www.thejimi.com/), which is great, but has no way to store coins. It was also inspired by the \"Wood Wallet\" by design group on Etsy (http://www.etsy.com/listing/42408406/wood-wallet). I wanted a way to store coins without them rattling around. It is a single solid piece construction. It has five cutouts for Australia\'s three largest denomination coins - $2, $1 and 50c. The coin holes have access cutouts so you can remove the coins without tipping the whole thing upside down. Bank notes are folded in thirds and placed on top of the coins, and 4 credit cards are stacked on top and held down with a rubber band. The credit cards keep everything else from falling out. The wallet was design in Pro/Engineer WF2. It is fully parametric - you can change coin diameters etc. to suit the sizes of your currency (.prt file attached). I know Pro/E isn't very common or free/open source; I'm working on v2 in SketchUp.
Construction is a single 3D printing operation, or could also be milled.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3xlPAdcCebO

A spring-loaded printer foot to reduce noise and vibration. Currently designed for the MakerFarm Prusa i3, the .scad file is included for your custom needs.  
I'm using four right now, and the printer is really bouncing around, and the print is looking pretty messy. I'll try adding another pair in the middle, to see if that helps, once I get more springs.  
Relocating the feet to different areas of the printer. It turns out having the printer resting on feet in the front and back only caused the Y axis to flex a little bit, and that's what made the print messy, not the bouncing.

I designed this foot to fit the front and rear frame pieces of the MakerFarm Prusa i3, the two places with a double thickness of wood.   
The springs I purchased in a pack of four, type C-632 from www.centuryspring.com. The spring dimensions are 11.125 x 27 x 1.041mm. They just press-fit into the holes in the feet.  ("C-632" is what was on the plastic bag the springs came in when I bought them at BMS. A search of the site shows that they are actually either A15-44 or S-876.)  
I also added some circular foam gripper pads I found at WalMart, for non-slip and extra sound damping.  
The scad file has variables you can change for thickness of the area where you'll mount these to the printer, foot diameter, and spring diameter.

comments.text: I had similar results trying to dampen a small, horizontal piston generator that walked around on the concrete floor. Spring feet didn't help at all... actually made it worse. The problem was the oscillating mass (piston / connecting rod) shakes everything from side to side, not vertically, and a vertical spring primarily work in the Z axis. But the inertial force which needed dampening was moving sideways. Tall, soft rubber foot pads cured most of it.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: I've found relocating the feet to two in the middle frame, behind the z motors, one by the y motor and the other by the y endstop cuts the bouncing down quite a bit, and doesn't flex the y axis as much, so no more messy prints.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: That worked. A short piece of tubing inside each spring, short enough so the spring still has some give, but long enough to act as a shock absorber. It still bounces, but not nearly as bad.
comments.author: AbuMaia

comments.text:
Good job..
There's an entire science devoted to curing machine vibration problems, but still everyone struggles with it. Solutions are tough to come by.

title: CR-10 Flexible Magnetic Build Plate DIY

description.text:
Just upgraded to a DIY Magnetic Build plate for the CR-10 (300x300) - Absolutely Amazing!

I know others can benefit from this, so while this upload doesn't include any real STL's, it bundles all the info together into a searchable format.

LokBuild $20: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072MZRM2P
Any adhesive backed build sheet should work.(LokBuild, BuildTak, PEI, Gluestick, Tape, etc..)

1095 Spring Steel (0.016") $27: https://www.mcmaster.com/#9036K992

Magnetic Sheet (0.032") $5: https://www.mcmaster.com/#5775K8 (150°F, 80°C Max)

Adjustable Z-Stop: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2158261

Bed Leveling Wedge: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779077

Directions:
1.) Remove factory glass from CR-10
2.) Install Adjustable Z-axis stop and lower all the way.
3.) Clean Spring Steel, Stick build plate to spring steel
4.) Clean CR-10 aluminum heated bed plate, Stick magnet sheet to CR-10
5.) Attempt to level bed. If middle of bed plate is low, install Bed wedge(s)

title: Lattice Structures - Mikrostrukturen
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE

ENGLISH:

My second print of these cube micro structures was done in Photocentric clear flexible UV Laser Resin on my Form 2 with the Standard Clear V2 Settings in OpenMode. Here is the video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cE_UwaZH2pk

DEUTSCH:

Mein zweiter Druck der Mikrostruktur Würfel ist mit Photocentric Clear Flexible Resin auf meinem Form2 mit den Standard Clear V2 Settings im offenen Modus entstanden.

Hier ist das Video dazu https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zexrf9MhyqA

Lattices - Microstructures

Lattice structures normally are intended to optimize functional parts by making them light-weight and strong by filling the inside with a complex structure. This is used in aerospace technology to save on fuel while flying and still maintaining structural integrity and strength of the parts that are optimized.

Nowadays these structures can be achieved with metal 3D printing (laser sintering, laser melting and the like). But these structures are also interesting from a design perspective. The pure beauty of them inspires to use these structures in architecture, fashion or other fields.

Here are my tests with different topologies, printed on a Formlabs Form2 (SLA printing) with clear UV resin. If you want to create your own structures head over to NTopolgy (https://www.ntopology.com) they have a beautiful free tool for that.

You will find more footage next week on my Instagram, Facebook and Youtube accounts.

I hope you got inspired like me and get hands-on designing. Let me know in the comments what projects you came up with.

Cheers RobotMama.

comments.text: Wow! Very Nice Do you print without supports on form2? It looks like no.. how do you prevent it from failing? Do you ever have issues with adhesion?
comments.author: tangtang

comments.text: I print it with supports only attached to the lowest elements to make it stick better to the platform, the structures wouldn’t need supports as they are all self supportive but the strands are so delicate that there isn’t enough area sticking to the platform so the lattices will easily drop if you don’t use supports.
comments.author: tangtang

comments.text: Beautiful! My current printer isn't capable of this, but I hope to have a better one someday soon!
comments.author: Shalonne

comments.text: You can also print this with an FDM printer (I assume you have one of this type), the only thing you have to make sure is that the thickness of your structures is fitting the size of your printers nozzle. Take, for example, the lower left structure of my first image. It has thicker struts, most of these structures do not even need support structures.
comments.author: Shalonne

comments.text: I'm not sure what FDM is. I have a New Matter Mod-T.
comments.author: drato

comments.text: Yep thats an FDM printer, FDM means Fused Deposition Modeling. The Formlabs Form2 is an SLA printer (Stereo Lithography Aparatus).

title: Frame de acero corte al laser 3mm Anet A8 (Modificacion de la Tatara) - 3mm Lasercutted Steel frame fot Anet A8 (Modificated Tatara)

description.text:
Plano para corte por laser para hacer un frame compatible con la impresora 3D Anet A8.

Acero de corte por laser de 3mm de espesor.

Compatible con las piezas de dicha impresora.

Modificaciones partiendo de la base de la Tatara: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2221391

Con las siguientes características o modificaciones:

  • Se ha quitado la sujeción de la pantalla. Si se quiere acoplar la pantalla al frame, habrá que hacer una base impresa. (Hay agujeros en la parte superior para poder sujetar la base).

  • Se le ha quitado el refuerzo inferior y creado 6 escuadras para rigidizar la estructura despues de quitar el refuerzo.

  • Las escuadras tienen agujero para poder poner SilentBlocks en caso de querer ponerlos.

  • Posibilidad de poner perfil+carril+carro en vez de varilla de 8mm de diametro+carro+rodamiento lineal en el eje Y. (Por ejemplo, carriles y carros tipo hiwin12).

  • Posibilidad de poner perfil+carril+carro en vez de varilla de 8mm de diametro+carro+rodamiento lineal en el eje Z. (Por ejemplo, carriles y carros tipo hiwin12).

  • Posibilidad de calibrar la cama con 3 puntos en vez de con 4.

  • Posibilidad de poner el carro del extrusor (eje X) en vertical (como en la Anet A8) o en horizontal (como en la Anet A6). Se supone que el frame también es compatible con la Anet A6. (No está testado al 100% la compatibilidad con la Anet A6).

  • Se ha quitado del plano la "H" de sujeción de la cama. (En el plano Nº2 se ha añadido una "H" con otro diseño, para poder hacer el corte de todas las piezas en el caso de desearlo).

  • Para el tensor del eje Y y los finales de carrera de Y y Z es necesario imprimir una pieza en cada caso. (Se incluyen las piezas, que están sacadas de: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2358104)

Plane to make a frame for Anet A8 3D printer with laser cutted steel of 3mm.

Compatible with original the parts of said printer.

Modifications based on the Tatara: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2221391

With the following characteristics or modifications:

  • The grip for the screen has been removed. If you want to attach the screen to the frame, you have to make a printed base. (There are holes in the upper part to hold the base).

  • The lower reinforcement has been removed and 6 squares created to stiffen the structure after removing the reinforcement.

  • The squares have a hole to put SilentBlocks in case you want to put them.

  • Possibility of getting profile + rail + trolley instead of 8 mm diameter rod + trolley + linear bearing on the Y axis. (For exmple hiwin12 rails and trolleys).

  • Possibility of getting profile + rail + trolley instead of 8 mm diameter rod + trolley + linear bearing on the Z axis. (For exmple hiwin12 rails and trolleys).

  • Possibility of calibrating the bed with 3 points instead of 4.

  • Possibility of placing the extruder carriage (X axis) vertically (as in Anet A8) or horizontally (as in Anet A6). It is assumed that the framework is also compatible with the Anet A6. (The compatibility with teh Anet A6 is no tested at 100%).

  • The "H" to hold the bed has been removed from the plane. (In plane Nº2, an "H" with another design has been added, in order to make the cut of all the pieces if it is desired).

  • For the Y-axis tensioner and the Y and Z limit switches, it is necessary to print one part in each case. (The two pieces are included, they are from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2358104).

title: Thrustmaster T16000M FCS HOTAS Table Mount

description.text:
I didn't want the Joystick and the Throttle blocking space on my Desk, so I made a Simple but very sturdy construction for mounting my HOTAS to my table. It's very easy to take those mounts of and set them aside. For the Dimensions I used, please view the Images.

The Thrustmaster Throttle and Joystick have Mounting Points, so you will need 4x M616mm. I also Added a cable-clip to connect the cable from the Throttle with the one from the Pedals if you use them.

For the Prints you need a 200x200mm Print Bed!
There are Build in Supports for better Printing Results.

Here is what you need to build your own:
(Links are exemplary)

2x 32mm Toggle Clamps
(https://de.aliexpress.com/item/32mm-Plunger-Stroke-Metal-Push-Pull-Toggle-Clamp-227Kg-500-Lbs/32753112723.html)
12x 2020 L Connectors
(https://de.aliexpress.com/item/10PC-T-slot-L-type-90-degree-EU-standard-2020-aluminum-profile-Inside-corner-connector-bracket/32799109924.html)
2x 500mm 2060 Aluminum Extrusion Profile [or more depending on your measurements]
(https://de.aliexpress.com/item/2060-aluminum-extrusion-profile-european-standard-length-500mm-aluminum-profile-workbench-1pcs/32830372532.html)
34x M4 T-Nuts
(https://de.aliexpress.com/item/10PCS-M5-Hammer-Nut-Aluminum-Connector-T-Fastener-Sliding-Nut-Nickel-Plated-Carbon-Steel-for-2020/32623642406.html)
34x M4x10 Allen Bolts (For Corner Brackets and Plates)
8x M4x40 Allen Bolts (For Toggle Clamps)
8x M5 Washers (For Toggle Clamps with M4 Bolts)

Mounting everything together should be pretty self explaining.
Tablet Mount is Optional and requires 1x M4x10 Bolt 1xM4 Washer and 1x T-Nut

Have fun Printing!

title: Secure Mount for Tiva C Series LaunchPad

description.text: This housing holds a Tiva C Series TM4C123G LaunchPad microcontroller, which is used in the edX Embedded Systems course from UTAustinX, found here: https://www.edx.org/course/utaustinx/utaustinx-ut-6-01x-embedded-systems-1172 The board is fragile and awkward to handle, so I developed this housing to be part of a plate to which this and a breadboard will be secured. There is an access port along the right side, under the reset switch, intended for routing wires under the housing into the headers under the board. The holes on the top and bottom ends are for a cover I eventually intend to add to the design. Included with the files for the thing are the beginnings of a model of the board itself and a primitive model of a micro USB cable for reference.

So i created this thing, which hold the Spool itself, guids the filament and with some cleaningmaterial glued under the guide it cleans the filament.

It works perfekt for me, i've never had a the filament going down from the spool.

description.text:
Hello printers! Welcome to yet another 3D printable! This time, I bring you the Twitter logo on a stand! Use it to show that you have a Twitter account, or to just show off your love for Twitter!
All the fun stuff aside, there are some recommendations for this 3D printable. Depending on the 3D printer you have, support may be needed for the Twitter logo. You may be wondering why... Let me clarify! when you look on the bottom of the 3D printable in your 3D object software, there will be a hole. That's where you slide the Twitter logo onto the stand. I highly doubt that you will need supports since printers now have been far more improved than the ones back in 2014. Just be sure it needs supports before printing.
Size won't affect the quality of the print at all, unless you're that one person who owns a Creality Cr-10 S5 like I will in a couple months... Then quality will be affected due to the size of the polygons. Just be cautious if printing at 500mm size.
Anyways, I can't wait to see the pictures of the printable on people's desks and tables when I check the made section! Hope to see some made photos! Happy printing!

~Sydical

author: IamTheVector

description.text: Tubular 12 compartment cave for nano shrimp and similar.

scaling and functionality

IMPORTANT: in order to print at design zize (50mmx30mmx25mm) most setup programs (for example CURA) require the design to be scaled x10 times.

This specific piece is designed to house neocaridina davidi and palmata and similar zized crustaceans, but can be scaled in order to house bigger animals.

this tube-like cave array is one of the most used structures when it comes to housing and breeding shrimp and certain species of fish. Also it's design allows for an esay cleanup an the printing texture allows Biofilm an other plant matter to grow in its surface (many shrimp and fish species are known for eating this plant matter).

This thing is an upgrade for Creality Cr-10 3d fdm printer.
Bars collectors are designed for 19-20 mm tubes.
Contact me or comment for others diameters.

I suggest printing it on your printer's finest layer setting, as the threads are very small.
